Dear Ms. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
July 26, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following.
R 400.4505 Plans and specifications.
Rule 505. (1) Plans and specifications shall be submitted to
the bureau of fire services for review and approval prior to any
remodeling in an institution, or the construction or conversion
of a structure for use as an institution.
(2) The plans shall comply with all of the following provisions:
(a) Show layout, room arrangements, construction materials
to be used, and the location, size, and type of fixed equipment.
(b) For additions, show those portions, including existing exits,
types of construction, and room occupancies, which may be
affected by the addition.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility had two special investigations during this reporting period with only one
investigation requiring a CAP. The CAP addressed a staff member antagonizing
youth. The facility has successfully complied and completed the CAP.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on a review of the annual financial
report.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported the goal of the facility is to have youth placed in
the home by mid-August. Eagle Village requested to decrease the capacity in
Leppien from 15 to 9 youth and change their program to short-term intensive
stabilization. A change application was provided as well as updated policies,
procedures, and program statement. Eagle Village Leppien will be a short-term
intensive stabilization program providing a therapeutic environment for males and
females ages 8 -17 years old. Although the facility is licensed for males and
females, at this time only males will be moving into the program.
Staff and Youth Interviews
3

Currently there are no youth placed at the facility so there are no staff working at
the facility.
Currently there are no youth placed at the facility.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on July 5 and July 26,
2023. There are two hallways upon entering the house. The hallway to the left,
once entering the house, is closed with a locked door to the youth in the house.
The bedrooms located in this hallway are part of the clothing closet and incentive
store for youths placed at the facility. No youth will reside in this space. There is a
separate door youth will use to gain access to the clothing closet and incentive
store. The hallway to the right when entering the house, consists of seven
bedrooms that can have one or two, same gender youth to a room, depending
upon the room size. There were no issues or safety concerns noted during the
walkthrough.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license
and the licensing terms be updated to a capacity of 9 youth, male or female, ages 8-17.
